(Critical)

(Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/traits/mod.rs] [Trait: Convert] [Generic type exploit] Since Convert uses generic types ToType and AuxType, can an attacker exploit Rust's type system to instantiate Convert with types that violate cryptographic invariants, such as using non-prime-order groups or weak cryptographic parameters? Can an attacker provide inputs that cause extremely expensive conversions (e.g., requiring exponential-time computations), leading to validator DoS and loss of liveness? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/traits/mod.rs] [Trait: Convert] [Trait bound missing] The Convert trait has no trait bounds on ToType or AuxType. [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/traits/mod.rs] [Trait: Convert::to()] [Zero value handling] Can the Convert::to() method be exploited when converting zero/identity elements? Could this allow an attacker to contribute zero secrets to DKG, enabling threshold reduction attacks where fewer than t parties can reconstruct secrets? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/traits/mod.rs] [Trait: Convert] [Panic safety] Are Convert trait implementations panic-safe? Can malicious inputs to Convert::to() trigger panics that crash validator nodes during critical DKG operations, causing loss of liveness? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/traits/mod.rs] [Trait: HasEncryptionPublicParams] [Lifetime issues] Does the returned reference lifetime properly prevent use-after-free scenarios where encryption parameters are accessed after the HasEncryptionPublicParams object is dropped during DKG execution?
